WIAA Season 3: Volleyball, Girls Soccer, 1B/2B Boys Soccer, Football

Good Morning,

Reopening school in the fall is on many people’s minds right now and I wish I could say I have a crystal clear picture of what it will look like.
The pandemic and our response as a community, state and nation are in constant flux.
What I do know, is we are trying to plan for every possible scenario.
In response to current guidance, we are planning to provide students with an all-remote learning option or a hybrid model where they come to school in person two or more days a week.
If the situation with the pandemic continues as it is right now, we will need to be ready to pivot to Continuous Learning 2.0, a much more robust version of our experience in the Spring.

District office staff continue planning to ensure we are ready for what comes.

I am thankful we have such a dedicated team!

As things change and as we get closer to the start of the year, we will let you know what is happening.

For now, thank you for your commitment to our students!
Best,
Dana Rosenbach

Good Morning,

Theler wetlands will reopen for walkers on May 5 in accordance with state guidelines on staying at home and staying healthy. If you come, please follow appropriate social distancing guidelines.

“Outdoor recreation is one of the best things we can do promote physical, mental and emotional well-being for Washingtonians during a time of great stress and isolation. And springtime in our state is Washington at its best and people want to be out enjoying outdoor activities in a safe and responsible way.” Governor Inslee

When you get there
• Avoid crowds. Be prepared to go somewhere else or come back another time if it looks crowded.
• Practice physical distancing. Keep six feet between you and those outside your immediate household. Leave at least one parking space between your vehicle and the vehicle next to you.
• Wash your hands often. Keep up on personal hygiene and bring your own water, soap, and hand sanitizer with you.
• Pack out what you pack in. Take any garbage with you, including disposable gloves and masks.

Dear North Mason Families,

Normally, we would all be coming back to school from Spring Break and discussing all the fun places we went. However, in this unprecedented time we are still at home.

When schools were originally closed, the directions we were given from the State were to give out meaningful work for our students. However, now that the continuous learning has been extended for the rest of the school year, things have changed. The Admin and Teachers are working hard to get work to our students that will be graded, and feedback given by their teachers.

Last week was Spring Break for our students and staff. Our staff are back to work creating lesson plans today to get out to their students. Communication from your teachers will start back up this week.

Our buildings may be closed, but we will continue the learning and services that will be vital to our families, students and community during this difficult time.

If you have any questions or concerns, please let us know. We appreciate your patience in this ongoing challenging time.

The suspension will not affect our before/after-school student related activities.

While we are relying on our County Health Departments and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) for guidance, our overall continued safety of our students and staff is our highest priority when making decisions.

For any questions, please call the District Office
at 360-277-2300.

The North Mason HS athletic department has announced that Rob Thomas and Mark Swofford will be the varsity baseball coaches to replace Coach Bill Geyer.

Rob has been an assistant coach for the past four years under Coach Geyer and will bring stability to the program after the passing of Coach Geyer. Rob is well-respected for his commitment to kids, his passion for anything that has to do with the Bulldogs, and his organizational skills. Although Coach Geyer will certainly be missed, Coach Thomas is well suited to keep the positive momentum that the program achieved during the 2019 season. Coach Thomas is also the offensive coordinator on the NMHS football staff.

Mark Swofford, the NMHS athletic director for the past 24 years, has announced his retirement this June. Before that time however, he will join Coach Thomas in leading this year's baseball team. Coach Swofford was the head baseball coach for six seasons at both Curtis HS (1982-1987) and Kentridge HS (1991-1996) before coming to North Mason in the fall of 1996.

Hands on Art is a new program provided for all students in grades 3-5. Four art projects will be offered to students this year. Did you know?

To the individual taxpayer the increase of 37 cents from $1.99/$1,000 to $2.36/$1,000 would equate to an 18.6% increase in what they are currently paying.

If the District were able to collect the full amount of the levy in the first year ($5.9M), it would equate to a $1.3M revenue increase over the levy dollars budgeted to be collected in 2020 ($4.6M). This is a 28.3% increase.

For comparison: In 2016, when our last levy was approved at $2.36/$1,000, the state minimum wage was $9.47. In 2020, the minimum wage is $13.50. This is an increase of 42.6%. The costs from our vendors have gone up drastically with the increasing minimum wage as the vendors have passed the wage increases on to their consumers.

This week is School Bus Safety Week. Here is today's tip:

Getting On and Off the Bus:

* Warn children that if they drop something getting on and off the bus, they should never pick it up. Instead, they should tell the driver and follow the driver’s instructions.

* Remind children to look to the right before they step off the bus.

* If you meet your child at the bus stop after school, wait on the side where the child will be dropped off, not across the street. Children can be so excited to see you after school that they dash across the street and forget the safety rules.

* Teach your child if they must be crossed to wait at the end of the crossing arm, look at the driver and wait for the signal from the driver that it is safe to cross.

* While crossing continue to look left and right.

This week is School Bus Safety Week. Here is today's tip:

At the Bus Stop:

* Have children wait in a location where the driver can see them while driving down the street. Try to avoid waiting in a house or car.

* Do not let children play in the street. Playing with balls or other toys that could roll into the street is also dangerous.

* Use a flashlight (there is a flashlight function on cell phones) during twilight and darkness hours to help with visibility and wear lighter colored clothes.

This week is School Bus Safety Week. Here is today's tip:

Walking to the Bus Stop:

* Walk young children to the bus stop or encourage children
to walk in groups. There is safety in numbers; groups are easier for drivers to see.

* Practice good pedestrian behavior: walk on the sidewalk, and if there is no sidewalk stay out of the street. If you must walk in the street, walk single file, face traffic and stay as close to the edge of the road as you can.

* Stop and look left, right and then left again if you must cross the street. Do the same thing at drive -ways and alleys. Exaggerate your head turns and narrate your actions so your child knows you are looking left, right and left.

* Use a flashlight (there is a flashlight function on cell phones) during twilight and darkness hours to help with visibility and wear lighter colored clothes.

What is Skyward Family Access?

Skyward Family Access is an easy-to-use website that allows parents and guardians to access information about their students at North Mason from any computer with Internet access.

Skyward Family Access features:

One login allows parents/guardians to view the records of all students within a single family, even if they are at different North Mason schools.

Parents and guardians can access the following features:
Student and emergency contact information.
Assignments and grades (for certain grade levels).
Attendance.
Class schedules.
Food service account.
Register to vote
In addition, this year we are excited to announce that parents/guardians will be able to complete the Impact Aid Survey form electronically in Skyward Family Access.

Follow the link for more information:
